intro: Athroandra inopinata, commonly known as the black mangrove, is a species of flowering plant in the family Myrtaceae. It is native to the coastal regions of southern Florida, the Caribbean, and parts of Central and South America. This plant is characterized by its dark, almost black bark and its ability to thrive in saline and waterlogged soils. It has small, elliptical leaves and produces fragrant, white flowers that bloom in clusters. The fruit is a small, woody capsule that contains several seeds, contributing to its role in coastal ecosystems.
